urn:contentItem:5VVY-HD11-JCMN-Y53V-00000-00Disney CEO Bob Iger reportedly said that 'Hitler would have loved social media' (FB, TWTR)2019-04-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:40:23ZLexisNexisDisney CEO Bob Iger reportedly said that 'Hitler would have loved social media' (FB, TWTR)Rob Price

Apr 11, 2019( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Jordan Strauss/Invision/APDisney chief exec Bob Iger says that "Hitler would have loved social media." The high-profile entertainment exec lashed out at companies like Twitter and Facebook at an awards dinner. It shows how the public mood towards social media has shifted — a few years ago, Disney even considered acquiring Twitter.

Disney CEO Bob Iger said that "Hitler would have loved social media" in an aggressive attack on big tech firms like Facebook and Twitter. Variety is reporting that the high-profile entertainment industry exec spoke out[1] during a speech at an awards dinner hosted by the Simon Wiesenthal Center, lamenting the state of public discourse and laying the blame in part with social media companies. 'Hitler would have loved social media," he is reported to have said. "It's the most powerful marketing tool an extremist could ever hope for because by design social media reflects a narrow world view filtering out anything that challenges our beliefs while constantly validating our convictions and amplifying our deepest fears. "It creates a false sense that everyone shares the same opinion. Social media allows evil to prey on troubled minds and lost souls and we all know that social news feeds can contain more fiction than fact, propagating vile ideology that has no place in a civil society that values human life." Iger's remarks are indicative of how the public mood has turned against big tech companies, and dramatically so. Companies like Facebook were once lauded, but following years of scandals there has been increasing public and regulatory scrutiny of their practices and their impact on society. It's also a significant shift for Iger and Disney's stance on social media. Back in 2017, the chief exec confirmed that Disney had considered buying Twitter[2] — describing it as a "a compelling way that we might be able to present and sell the content our company makes to the consumer." urn:contentItem:60K1-S301-JDVW-N0B9-00000-00Disney surges on 'Mulan' streaming plans; Microsoft sees TikTok deal boost2020-08-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:40:23ZLexisNexisMARKETWEEKExclusiveDisney surges on 'Mulan' streaming plans; Microsoft sees TikTok deal boostAnna Akins, David DiMolfetta

The S&P 500 rebounded this week as some major technology companies reported positive earnings results and others revealed M&A news.

The S&P 500 rebounded this week as some major technology companies reported positive earnings results and others revealed M&A news.

Walt Disney Co.'s shares jumped the week ended Aug. 7, even after the company reported a $2.9 billion income hit for its June quarter due to impacts from the coronavirus pandemic.

Disney's parks, experiences and products segment took the biggest blow, reporting revenues of $983 million for the fiscal third quarter, down 85% year over year. All of Disney's domestic parks and resorts, its cruise line business and Disneyland Paris were closed for the entirety of the just-ended period as social-distancing measures and shelter-in-place mandates took effect globally.

The company also said it plans to debut its live-action "Mulan" remake originally scheduled to open in theaters this spring but postponed multiple times amid COVID-19 as a premium-priced offering on its Disney+ streaming service.

"Mulan" will be available to Disney+ subscribers in most of its markets on Sept. 4. In the U.S., the film will cost Disney+ subscribers an additional $29.99, with retail pricing varying slightly in other markets.

Fitch Ratings Managing Director Patrice Cucinello called the "Mulan" announcement "somewhat of a surprise departure" from Disney's previously "unwavering support" of the theatrical exhibition model. Cucinello also predicted that the longer the effects of COVID-19 persist, the higher the risk of a "more permanent structural shift" for the business models of movie theaters.

Disney stock closed Aug. 6 trading up roughly 12% from its July 31 close, at $130.85 each.

Gaming company Take-Two Interactive Software Inc. also saw its shares jump after the company reported solid results in its fiscal first-quarter earnings.

Take-Two offered a full-year outlook of net revenue between $2.80 billion and $2.90 billion, driven by increased sales volume and player engagement amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Fiscal first-quarter revenue for the period ended June 30 was $831.3 million, up from $540.5 million in the prior-year period.

"I do think that people have come back to video games and tried video games when they hadn't tried them previously," Take-Two CEO Strauss Zelnick said on an earnings call.

The company's stock closed Aug. 6 trading up 8.12% for the week.

Meanwhile, Microsoft Corporation got a boost after it provided details about its plan to buy TikTok Inc. assets.

Microsoft said it intends to move forward with plans to acquire the U.S. operations of video-sharing app TikTok, with the goal of completing negotiations with its Chinese parent company Beijing Byte Dance Telecommunications Co. Ltd. by Sept. 15.

Even though Microsoft faces hurdles from several top lawmakers in Washington who have voiced national security concerns about the acquisition, analysts largely expect the deal to close successfully and are bullish on the tie-up.

For instance, Wedbush Securities analyst Daniel Ives predicted that there is at least a 75% chance the deal will secure approval given that Microsoft has remained largely out of the regulatory spotlight compared to other big tech companies.

Microsoft closed Aug. 6 trading up 5.53% from its July 31 close.

Microchip Technology Inc., however, fell after the microcontroller and circuits manufacturer lowered its outlook for the current quarter.

Microchip's net sales for the first quarter of fiscal year 2021 was $1.31 billion, down just 1% from the prior-year period, but the company's outlook was lowered because sales have fallen for four consecutive quarters.

CEO Steve Sanghi acknowledged business orders for the June quarter were "soft" compared to the March period, "as our customers and distributors did not have the visibility to place long-term orders."

The company closed Aug. 6 trading down 2.50% for the week.

urn:contentItem:5V45-5MB1-JCMN-Y2TC-00000-00Dispensed: A $74 billion mega-merger starts 2019 off with a bang and how a health system plans to disrupt itself before it's disrupted2019-01-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:40:23ZLexisNexisDispensed: A $74 billion mega-merger starts 2019 off with a bang and how a health system plans to disrupt itself before it's disruptedLydia Ramsey

Jan 04, 2019( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Hollis Johnson/Business Insider Hello, and Happy New Year! Hope you all had a restful end to 2018, because 2019's here and it's hitting the ground running. I guess I should've known that the week before a major healthcare conference[1] would not necessarily be a slow week for news, even with a holiday on a Tuesday to divide up the week. With the full Business Insider healthcare team back online this week, and a mega-merger and $1 billion funding round on the same day[2], there was plenty to keep us busy.

New to our weekly newsletter? Youcan sign up here[3]. To start, the healthcare and finance teams at BI were all over the Bristol-Myers Squibb-Celgene $74 billion merger news that hit on Thursday. From covering the breaking news of the deal's announcement[4], which made it the largest healthcare deal on record when factoring in debt. To dissecting the reaction investors had to the deal (analysts are skeptical a combination will heal each company's issues[5]). We looked at the "synergies" the combined company hopes to achieve by joining forces and what that could mean for employees at the pharma and biotech giants[6]. BMS said it expects to realize $2.5 billion in synergies by 2022, which could mean jobs are on the table[7]. And a tiny boutique bank landed a big role in the massive deal[8]. Finance reporter Alex Morrell has the story on what that bank is all about. And in case you missed it over the holidays, Erin Brodwin[9], as always, has been keeping close tabs on marijuana-related regulations. On the heels of hemp legalization, regulators have fired a 'warning shot' to the $1 billion CBD industry[10]Earlier in December, Trump signed the US Farm Bill into law. It legalizes hemp, a plant that's roughly identical to marijuana and is a key source of the highly touted wellness ingredient CBD. Hours after the law was passed, regulators released a statement emphasizing their power to police CBD retailers, which already make up a roughly $1 billion industry. Analysts called the move a "warning shot" to the thousands of cafes and stores selling CBD drinks, snacks, and supplements. Erin also had the story on what Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg is up to in health these days. Three words: implantable brain devices.A group of Mark Zuckerberg-funded researchers is testing implantable brain devices as part of a $5 billion quest to end disease[11]Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg and his pediatrician wife, Priscilla Chan, have sold 29 million Facebook shares to raise $5 billion for an ambitious biomedical-research program called the Chan-Zuckerberg Initiative (CZI). Related to the CZI is the Chan-Zuckerberg Biohub, which employs top-notch scientists from Stanford University, UC Berkeley, and UC San Francisco. Researchers including a Biohub investigator are studying a wireless implantable brain device, called the "Wand" for short, in primates. Published on New Year's Eve, their first study details how the Wand records, stimulates, and disrupts movement in real time. Emma Court[12] took a look at what pharmaceutical drugs investors are keeping an eye on this year that's definitely a good primer for the week (and year) ahead.From the gene therapy that spurred a $9 billion acquisition to a CBD medication for rare types of childhood epilepsy, here are the 12 promising drugs to watch in 2019[13]Investors should keep an eye on 12 key new drugs going into 2019, according to Jefferies analyst Michael Yee. The medications range from a gene therapy that could be a game-changer for a rare disease to a CBD product for rare childhood epilepsy and a fish-based drug that could improve heart health. But new drug launches can be a bumpy time for companies, so buying shares in these drugmakers may not make sense, Yee said. Emma last week also spoke to a Yale researcher who had a warning for those working on cancer immunotherapy.A Yale scientist who pioneered a cutting-edge approach to cancer treatment is warning that the field is going off-course — and that drug giants could be making it worse[14]A leading Yale scientist whose work helped a cutting-edge approach to cancer called immunotherapy get off the ground is now warning that the field has lost touch with the fundamental science. If current trends continue, "we are going to see a lot of negative trials in cancer patients," the researcher, Dr. Lieping Chen, told Business Insider. Chen is particularly concerned about an approach that large firms like Bristol-Myers Squibb and Boehringer Ingelheim are taking. Yet another pioneering cancer scientist, whose company is focused on this space, said the worries could be unfounded. A new year brings a new crop of price increases to the drug industry as well. Emma ran through the new increases from Allergan, BMS, Biogen, and others, with insight into whether 2019 might be the year we actually see policy changes that curb these increases.Trump may have shamed Pfizer for increasing drug prices, but that isn't stopping drugmakers from doing more of the same[15]Since President Donald Trump called out Pfizer and other drugmakers for prescription drug price increases in July, the issue has largely stalled. Now, though, pharmaceutical companies are implementing new drug price hikes. One expert predicted that the increases could even be larger than usual. Expect to hear a lot more about the cost of drugs this year. Finally, ahead of JPMorgan, I wrapped up some of my reporting from my December trip to Seattle. A big focus of mine that week — surprise surprise — was looking at where tech is intersecting with healthcare out there. Here's what I gathered from my conversations with health execs: The hospital in Amazon's backyard has a plan to disrupt itself before being disrupted by big tech companies[16] We got 6 big predictions about how Amazon could disrupt healthcare from execs in the tech giant's backyard[17] Erin, Zach Tracer[18], and I will be out in San Francisco next week, so be sure to say hi if you're out and around Union Square as well! In the meantime, feel free to send tips, party invites, or general words of encouragement to get us through next week to the team at healthcare@businessinsider.com And as always, you can find me at lramsey@businessinsider.com; - LydiaNOW WATCH: Some animal fathers are impressive parents, like seahorse dads who give birth to 2,000 babies[19]See Also: Bristol-Myers Squibb and Celgene said their huge merger has about $2.5 billion in 'synergies.' That should make employees nervous.[20]Here's why Bristol-Myers Squibb's record-breaking $74 billion biotech deal is facing investor backlash[21]The largest Q4 digital health funding deals went to urn:contentItem:603V-96S1-DYTM-90R2-00000-00Dispossessed Prosumption, Crowdsourcing, and the Digital Regime of Work.2019-03-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:40:23ZLexisNexisPg. 52Dispossessed Prosumption, Crowdsourcing, and the Digital Regime of Work.Ettlinger, Nancy

INTRODUCTION

Two decades before the end of the last millennium two different types of scholars independently discussed 'prosumption', in considerably different ways. Futurist Alvin Toffler (1) (1980) conceived the term in his book The Third Wave to refer to the ways in which consumers contribute to the production of services and goods they consume; thus 'pro' as in 'production' as the prefix to a modified experience of consumption. Toffler recognised the rapidly increasing do-it-yourself (DIY) industry in the wake of structural unemployment as well as the development of customised demand in which consumers contribute designs to the manufactured goods they buy. These trends persisted and deepened in the late twentieth-century as consumers increasingly produced their own services, such as checking in at airports and out at retail establishments. A year before the publication of Toffler's book, Michel Foucault spoke on the neoliberal subject at the College de France in his lecture series on neoliberalism, The Birth of Biopolitics; (2) without coining a particular term, and irrespective of his much debated value judgement of neoliberalism (3), he argued that neoliberal life obliterates the usual division between production and consumption because 'the man of consumption ... is a producer.

he produces his own satisfaction' (Biopolitics, p226). Unlike Toffler's empirically based account of prosumption, Foucault's neoliberal subject is a discursive construction drawn from his reading of neoliberal theorist Gary Becker regarding human capital. (4) Departing from Becker's institutional approach that argues for state investment in formal education to foster human capital available to firms, Foucault argued that people invest in themselves to produce their satisfaction such that neoliberal life is lodged neither in firms nor the state, but rather, in the subject (Biopolitics, p241). Both Foucault and Toffler drew attention to the interface of production and consumption, 'prosumption' as coined by Toffler, but whereas Toffler cast the blurring of conventional spheres in terms of emergent socio-economic trends, Foucault presented it as a matter of subjectivity. (5)

Both contextual and subjective elements of prosumption warrant critical attention in the new millennium because the dynamics of prosumption have changed to encompass a perverse dimension. (6) Beyond the persistence of DIY and consumer designs in the context of customised demand, digital consumers do not necessarily consume what they have produced--thus a case of dispossessed prosumption by which digital consumers are alienated from the rewards of their role in digital production. (7) Firms covertly collect, aggregate, code, and subsequently transform into algorithms data gleaned from digital subjects' internet activity such as web surfing, online purchases, as well as self-curated activity that can range from self-production on social media to the production of photos and videos for online audiences. (8) All these types of internet activity inform firms about actions to take on the consumer population, thereby shaping digital practices, subjectivities and choice. (9) Ironically, the algorithms firms use to govern digital life are based on the web activity of digital subjects; hence, digital governance is a recursive process. (10) Some consumers are aware of their role in the new corporate profitability and others are not, but all are unpaid for their implicit data 'donations,' giving new meaning to 'wageless life' (11) and underscoring Tiziana Terranova's declaration of 'free labour' in the digital economy. (12)

Disagreement about dispossessed prosumption in the digital era centres on the im/materiality of users' rewards for data donations. Some argue that irrespective of consciousness of their role in the corporate digital value chain, consumers fairly exchange their data for a service, and further, often find self-enhancement and build communities through their online activity. (13) In contrast, and from a more critical perspective, consumers implicitly have become workers subject to exploitation and alienation from the fruits of their labour as online activity becomes commodified by and for firms. (14) Also from a critical perspective, apparent immaterial rewards from online activity benefit firms by ensuring continued online engagement, sometimes resulting in addiction, which ensures continued profitability, echoing the ways in which tobacco addiction maintained the profits of tobacco firms in the twentieth-century. Irrespective of entertainment or social capital resulting from online activity, digital consumers nonetheless remain materially uncompensated. Some online activity can actually entail quite a bit of work, giving rise to the phrase 'produsers' as usage of platform choice requires work to use, produce, and evaluate information (Platforms and Hyperchoice, p5). From a critical vantage point, and as elaborated below, I suggest that the main problem with the conceptualisation of consumers-as-workers is that it is partial.

Accepting that digital consumers represent unpaid labour and are dispossessed prosumers, I call attention to conditions of work for digital producers--those who actively seek a wage through online means--and crucially, their relation to digital consumers. I ask in what ways digital producers also are dispossessed prosumers. Work in the digital era requires an expansive view to permit an overarching conceptualisation of the digital regime, which encompasses both consumers and producers. I emphasise commonalities among digital consumers and producers while identifying salient context-specific differences in processes of dispossessed prosumption.

In the ensuing sections, I argue at the outset that for-profit crowdsourcing (heretofore, 'crowdsourcing') is the principal corporate strategy in the digital era that governs capital-labour relations. (15) I suggest that crowdsourcing, which is recognised in the context of digital production, also pertains to digital consumption, illuminating fundamental objectifying relations of production through which dispossessed prosumption occurs across the so-called production/consumption divide. I use 'producer crowdwork/er' in reference to the overt relation between firms and digital producers who consciously decide to pursue a wage through online means, and 'consumer crowdwork/ er' in reference to the covert relation between firms and digital consumers who may engage with the digital economy consciously or unconsciously. Although producer and consumer crowdworkers share common problems, the processes through which those problems obtain often differ, and therefore require parsing and situating. The following sections pursue both contextual and subjective dimensions of dispossessed prosumption, first regarding how dispossessed prosumption configures uniquely in the digital era among producers, and second, regarding the vulnerability of both producer and consumer crowdworkers to addiction, on which firms capitalise at the base of digital value chains. Digital producers and consumers share conditions that lead to digital addictions, yet the digital value chains that profit from the same problem differ in consumption and production. I close by positioning the arguments I develop relative to modes of digital resistance to date, and then look to the future. An expansive approach to digital work suggests provocative possibilities for coalitional resistance across what has become a dated divide of consumption and production.

AN EXPANSIVE CONCEPTUALISATION OF CROWDSOURCING

I argue that digital producers and consumers share common ground by virtue of the capital-labour relation to which they both are subject, and accordingly I reference crowdsourcing, an organisational strategy adopted by firms, as the critical bridge between production and consumption in the digital era. (16) Whereas outsourcing connects firms and enables one firm to access the work of another firm's labour through an inter-firm contract, crowdsourcing for profit enables firms to access workers directly online, or indirectly through firms that broker relations between them and workers in a mode of production that disentangles all firms from employer status. Known generally as a production strategy, crowdsourcing has constructed a new capital-labour relation that signifies the informalisation of work while formal-sector firms shed considerable labour, capital, space, and transportation costs, and crucially, responsibilities to workers. (17) Yet while firms access digital workers seeking wages through online means overtly through platforms, they access data from consumers seeking consumption (of products, services, entertainment) or curated self-production for others' consumption covertly through surveillance and data scraping, without remuneration. Crowdsourcing digital producers and consumers therefore entails different processes, but the overarching strategy is the same, namely to reap rewards based on input from digital subjects while dispossessing them. At this juncture in the global economy, the digital age arguably is just in its infancy, with one foot in crowdsourcing, and another in outsourcing and more generally, flexible production strategies of the post-Fordist era (encompassing, for example, factory work in digital technologies that is slated for automation in the future). (18) I focus below specifically on the contours of crowdsourcing, broadly conceived, in the emergent digital economy.

While 'crowdsourcing' is a digital organisational strategy embraced by firms, 'crowdwork' refers to the activity as well as subjectivities of digital producers and consumers. At the outset I distinguish producer and consumer crowdwork by the intention of the former to earn a wage through digital means and the lack of such intention among the latter. As elaborated later, some producer crowdworkers find their work entertaining, and others actually become addicted, similar to many consumer crowdworkers, but all producer crowdworkers in any case expect a wage, and all corporate agents involved in transactions with producer crowdworkers understand and organise around this expectation, even if they decline to pay. Indeed, despite expectations, many producer crowdworkers are unpaid. Firms often require low to high-skilled producer crowdworkers to complete unpaid tasks to become eligible for paid tasks. For example, relatively low-skilled online work platforms such as Amazon's Mechanical Turk include many tasks for zero remuneration as 'Turkers' sign on to unpaid tasks to build a task profile so they can take on paid tasks. More skilled digital work on online martketplaces such as Upwork or Freelancer often entails a trial period whereby hopeful workers submit whole project plans for evaluation, which firms can use even if they don't hire applicants; (19) this situation is similar to crowdsourcing in open innovation whereby firms as well as governments send out an electronic call for innovations for online contests, and hopeful contestants compete, often with thousands others, for the winning prizes. (20) In addition to unpaid work for firms, many firms, simply stated, fail to pay (https://worldslongestinvoice.com/), and they can manoeuver such delinquency in the absence of formal employment contracts. As wageless work in the digital era proliferates, outcomes--such as whether income is earned--can be messy and blur the lines between digital production and consumption. Intentions therefore constitute a meaningful difference that connects with differences in the nature of digital value chains relative to producer and consumer crowdsourcing, elaborated later.

Differences in intentionality also are important because they have consequences, notably in different modes of resistance. As I elaborate in the last section, whereas critical producer crowdworkers have resisted by seeking change in conditions of work, (21) critical consumer crowdworkers have resisted by eliminating their role as implicit workers in the digital value chain and taking steps to preserve their right to privacy. (22) Recognising both digital consumers and producers as crowdworkers despite differences in intentionality, the question remains as to how producer crowdworkers might be cast as prosumers, and further, whether the processes by which they are dispossessed differ from, or are similar to, those that govern their consumer crowdworker counterparts.

PRODUCER CROWDWORKERS AS DISPOSSESSED PROSUMERS

Like consumer crowdworkers, producer crowdworkers are materially alienated and become dispossessed through loss of control over the fruits of their labour. In consumer crowdwork, the process unique to the digital era is data capture. In producer crowdwork, alienation and dispossession derive from longstanding processes of disproportionate value capture by firms that characterise capital-labour relations in capitalism at any time. However, I argue that there is a form of dispossession specific to the digital era, namely self-investment in unreimbursed capital costs, which is a unique requirement of crowdsourcing. Producer as well as consumer crowdworkers must self-fund the costs of software and electronic devices to access the internet, in turn to consume in the case of consumers, and to work for a wage in the case of producers on online work platforms marketplaces. In addition, some producer crowdworkers have other capital costs that can be substantial. For example, gig-economy workers, who provide on-the-ground services by way of a platform, self-fund the material basis of their services, such as cars as well as insurance in the case of Uber, and homes in the case of Airbnb. Producer crowdworkers who enter contests as they respond to online calls for innovations from firms or the government must self-invest in the capital costs of the inventions they submit. Dispossession among producer crowdworkers occurs as the costs of self-investment in crowdwork exceed, often considerably, the wage, which can be as little as zero.

Beyond the short-term, unreimbursed capital costs of producing for firms, medium to high-skilled producer crowdwork in particular incurs long-term investments in education. Whether pursuing traditional postsecondary and graduate education or vocational boot camps for trending jobs such as coding, digital subjects who strive for higher wages in medium to high-skilled work invest their time, money, energy, and their passions in education to realise their dreams of profitably engaging the digital economy. In contexts without a welfare state such as the United States, post-secondary and vocational education are privileges, not rights, which commonly require considerable financial investment that results in long-term debt. Further, financial investments encompass opportunity costs in unpaid training, internship programs, applications that require evidence of qualifications by way of submitting project designs and the like as part of applications, as well as undesirable paid work that an individual might consider a 'stepping stone' to future, more preferable work.

Desire figures prominently in the sacrifices that accumulate among entrepreneurial subjects scrambling to develop a career that will productively channel the talents in which they have invested. Subjects often fall into a 'passion trap'--trapped by their self-investment and desire in the precarious context of declining opportunities for stable careers. (23) Such efforts often are unrequited and produce an immaterial sense of alienation. Yet entrepreneurial subjects commonly continue to pursue their dreams, which form on the basis of an ethos of 'aspirational consumption,' as wannabe consumer lifestyles anchor the production of the self towards attaining career goals. (24) This situation obtains for those seeking careers both on and offline, although precarious conditions have deepened for producer crowdworkers of the 'cybertariat' (25) in light of the increasing informalisation of work in the digital era. Long-term investments in education among digital wage-seekers are acts of aspirational consumption from which others, notably firms as well as university researchers benefit, commonly leading to mounting debt as digital producers live on hope, self-capitalising through credit. (26) The problems of debt and credit that have been considered germane to neoliberal life pertain fundamentally to dispossessed prosumption among producer crowdworkers. (27)

Consistent with Foucault's discursive construction of the neoliberal subject, crowdworkers use the capital at one's disposal to become an enterprise of oneself, making use of one's abilities in multiple ways to become 'an abilities machine' to ensure continual productivity and ultimately, satisfaction (Biopolitics, p226, 229). Foucault's argument that people become entrepreneurs of themselves by productively using their disposable capital informs new dynamics, although in the new millennium, DIY producer crowdworkers commonly use credit and sink into debt as aspirational consumers in the absence of disposable income.

As the precarity wrought of the post-Fordist order deepens in the digital era, producer crowdworkers invest in their chances for economic stability. They become part of what Silvio Lorusso called the 'entreprecariat' whereby digital subjects work as if they own a company but without the paycheck, always engaged in 'the urgency to optimise time, their mind, their body, and their soul to deal with precarious conditions'. (28) Foucault's argument that neoliberalism signals the transformation of social problems into economic opportunity is apt. As Lorusso suggested, the apparent intransigence of precarity results in individuals managing themselves 24/7 while self-marketing through applications, CVs, and cover letters--sealed with hope (The Cybertariat, p65). Whereas workers of previous regimes earned a wage to buy consumer items, producer crowdworkers in the digital era work outside formal workplaces, in the spaces of homes, cars, cafes, even while on public transit, to earn wages that do not necessarily enable basic needs. They self-invest to become what Foucault called 'abilities machines' to work overtime or to work several jobs to patch together a living wage.

Consumption pertains to basic needs of the everyday as well as hope for a better future, and especially for young crowdworkers, for the opulent and hip lives celebrated and paraded on film, television, streaming logins, and related media. (29) Such crowdworkers may strive to embody a lifestyle to which they aspire, living on credit to self-capitalise, thereby fuelling the finance economy that enables their subjection. This is not to say that workers of previous regimes of work had no aspirations; rather, the point is that aspirational consumption--the potential to consume a lifestyle, even if unlikely--has become integral to digital work among the hopeful due largely to the required self-investment that uniquely characterises crowdwork. In this way, crowdsourcing dispossesses producer crowdworkers of both the control over their prosumption as well as their material and affective investments, commonly unrealised, in their selves.

INSIDE THE BLACK BOX OF DIGITAL DESIRES AMONG CONSUMER AND PRODUCER CROWDWORKERS

Desire associated with norms developed in the era of digital social and work relations drive the capitalisation process in the digital economy. The specific corporate strategies that foster addiction capitalise on subjects' desires, which can morph into addiction. (30) At issue, then, is precisely what the norms are that underwrite desire in the digital economy. Bernard Harcourt suggested that digital consumers inexorably desire exposure, even at the expense of privacy, although left unattended is that which drives the need, the desire, for exposure in the first place. (31) I suggest that the objectification of digital consumers and producers alike as 'disparate data points' produces atomisation of both social and work relations in the digital era. (32) This individuation of subjects activates the drive to communicate one's worth, one's value, to as many people as possible, thereby laying fertile ground for capitalisation by firms. By 'atomisation' I refer to the corporate colonisation and commodification of sociality and their subjective effects such as increasing isolation, the siloing of digital subjects who play games by themselves, socialise online, and work alone as formal workplaces become increasingly rare in the era of crowdsourcing.

The implicit work of consumer crowdworkers that results in firms' profit varies from consumers who simply surf the web to find information and/or purchase goods and services, to those who either work to make selections on choice-infused platforms or work to actively curate their personal data on social media to self-brand and publicise--expose--their views, purchases, activities, families and homes to broadcast who they are, how they live, what they think, and with whom they connect. (33) Physical disconnection from social relations prompts desire for exposure as digital subjects grope for connection and recognition as much as decent material conditions of living.

Software designers in Silicon Valley's big tech firms create value out of affect by manufacturing addiction. (34) These firms use platforms to attract and distract users' attention, (35) leveraging algorithms to lure consumer crowdworkers equipped with an array of electronic devices to continually click in and check contacts, messages, chats, 'friend' activity, and consumer deals in a way strikingly analogous to drug or junk-food addiction. (36) Whereas fast food and tobacco contain chemicals that make the body crave more, algorithms seduce with implicit rewards--being 'liked' for instance--that nudge subjects of the digital economy to continually augment their social networks, and in the process, view trending items available for purchase. Consumers who have developed awareness of the production process in which they are entangled, even with repulsion, nonetheless often continue their everyday online practices because the practices themselves have become addictive. Daren Brabham's interviews with designers for Threadless, an online t-shirt company that relies on producer crowdworkers both for design and evaluation of t-shirts, offers a glimpse into similar tendencies among producer crowdworkers: over 60 per cent of interviewees commented that designing for online contests was addictive. Why? Because '... even if you don't win, it's a constant motivation to continually put your work out there'. (37) Recognising material drives such as the need for income, the intention to expose oneself and one's work may have as much purchase among producer as among consumer crowdworkers.

While the prompt to pursue producer crowdwork may derive from desperation for a wage under precarious conditions of living, desire sustains the effort. Accordingly, firms capitalise on those desires. Uber, for example, controls its drivers algorithmically through strategies that entail continual positive and negative feedback via rewards and punishments to nudge drivers to perform as productively as possible. (38) Luke Munn's interviews with Uber drivers revealed that 'The combination of responsive data and real-time messaging ... transforms a dry offer into a gamified mission, harnessing the kind of level-up logic and micro dopamine hits that are well understood in the gaming and gambling industries'. (39) Sam Knight interviewed an Uber driver in London, who commented regarding pick-ups and the inability to know a destination until a passenger is in the car: 'It's like being in the bookies. It is very, very addictive'. (40) Anxious feelings of aloneness in the absence of a formal workplace and fear of wasting time (or what Silvio Lorusso called 'lazy shaming') magnifies the sense of precariousness. (41) Such feelings may help explain how the desire to achieve, to be accountable for one's future, to be continually productive by earning as much as possible can morph into addictive behaviour. One designer who had entered countless online contests commented:

So you hope you win this one, or perhaps the next, or the one after that. Eventually you do win, and the euphoria of winning fires you up to join even more contests. It's a pathetic cycle of excitement-discouragement-delight-dejection ... the design industry begins to resemble a factory of unpaid skilled labourers, working zealously for the promise of possible reward. (42)

In light of material and immaterial unrequited self-investment, many low to high-skilled producer crowdworkers struggle to survive, and often cope by working overtime or juggling multiple 'gigs'. Wages from high-end online work can be high, but on the condition that payment is received, and in the case of online contests, on the condition of winning; many online contests for innovations can draw many thousands of contributors across the global economy. (43) In light of the deregulated nature of crowdwork and the absence of worker rights, high-end crowdwork and the lives of many professionals also are precarious.

Like the precariat, the cybertariat, is internally diverse across classes, and many high-skilled producer crowdworkers often pursue low-skilled opportunities in the absence of alternatives. One Turker commented:

... around here even McDonald's and Walmart are NOT hiring. I have a degree in accounting and cannot find a real job, so to keep myself off the street I work 60 hours or more a week here on mTurk just to make $150-$200. That is far below minimum wage, but it makes the difference between making my rent and living in a tent. (44)

The undelivered promise of a stable job following formal training constitutes a formidable subjective frame of reference for many digital subjects as crowdsourcing overlaps with, and is in the process of eclipsing, outsourcing as a principal corporate strategy. The tension between hopeful possibilities and ruthless realities that have deepened in the digital era sheds light on new trajectories of precarious life asjobs become increasingly short-term, insecure, unstable, and moreover, increasingly exploitative in the absence of formal employment contracts and worker rights. Desire may or may not morph into addiction, but the aloneness of digital life combined with deepened precarity amplify the likelihood of such a transformation, on which firms capitalise at the base of their digital value chains.

DIGITAL VALUE CHAINS AMONG CONSUMER AND PRODUCER CROWDWORKERS

Needs, desire, and possible addiction are capitalised through digital value chains. With or without consciousness of their role in the digital value chain, consumer crowdworkers publicise their 'personal' value, and firms then subject the data to further rounds of curation that progressively produce value as data are continually re-presented and manipulated through various functions: data scraping, aggregation, coding, and the construction of algorithms that are intended to shape the crowd's purchasing patterns and ensure profit for the firms orchestrating the digital value chain. Firms may incorporate the various functions along the digital value chain internally, although firms increasingly both outsource these functions to other firms and crowdsource individual freelancers. Although Silicon Valley big-tech firms as well as globally active political firms such as Cambridge Analytica receive the main press, wide-ranging firms from small to large engage in data scraping from social media and the internet more generally, either internally or increasingly by both outsourcing and crowdsourcing to oversee the curation of consumer crowdworkers' personal digital data, for profit. A search on the web for 'small business data scraping' turns up numerous advertisements for both data-scraping outsourcing services through firms (e.g. https://www. promptcloud.com/blog/social-media-scraping-for-competitive-intelligence) and crowdsourcing services through independent freelancers (e.g. https:// www.upwork.com/o/jobs/browse/skill/data-scraping/).

Whereas consumer crowdworkers contribute data subject to a chain of activities that firms both outsource and crowdsource, digitally based producer work is crowdsourced through inter-firm networks. Producer crowdworkers contract either directly with a firm seeking low to high-skilled and even innovative work or, increasingly, indirectly with a third-party, and sometimes a fourth-party mediator in the case of market expansion to least developed places. (45) Like their precursors in the non-digital temporary-help industry, firms that broker relations between producer crowdworkers and firms seeking online services mediate but do not employ. Some online producer crowdworkers select tasks on online work platforms, while others, like gig-economy workers, are matched with clients through on-demand and marketplace platforms. (46) While producer crowdwork informalises work, producer crowdworkers nonetheless sign contracts with mediators that formally subject them to precarious, informal work conditions.

Although producer crowdworkers explicitly self-enrol in digital work whereas consumer crowdworkers may not, they both nonetheless are subjected to opacity and covert algorithmic manipulation over the course of digital value chains. The term 'algorithmic management' was coined at the Human-Computer Interaction Institute at Carnegie Mellon University to refer to the ways in which algorithms monitor, evaluate and classify producer crowdworkers. (47) In the case of online work platforms, some corporate mediators classify the global 'crowd' hierarchically relative to 'first' and 'third' world regions. (48) In the case of firms like Uber in the gig-economy, firms set prices and algorithmically 'nudge' drivers into overtime. (49) Analogous to covert automated processes well documented in the daily life of digital consumers, (50) such covert surveillance, monitoring, and determination in producer crowdwork likewise renders producer crowdwork precarious and exploitative due not only to asymmetrical power relations, opacity, and low wages, but also to acts of dispossession.

FRONTIERS OF DIGITAL RESISTANCE

Despite the daunting contextual and subjective constraints on consumer and producer crowdworkers, dispossessed prosumption in the digital era is far from final as critical, reflexive subjects have forged a new frontier of digital resistance. Beyond traditional protests such as petitions and on-the-ground strikes, critical producer and consumer crowdworkers have strategised to subvert the affordances of the digital infrastructure by configuring them to work for civic society rather than big-tech firms. (51) One specifically digital mode of resistance among producer crowdworkers engaged in both online work and gig economies has entailed the development of platform cooperatives, which aim to eliminate corporate mediation, the mode by which firms access workers. Members of platform cooperatives self-organise, self-market, and self-fund to illuminate democratic principles and maintain autonomy. Consumer crowdworkers--digital subjects not seeking a wage--have developed wide-ranging strategies, including obfuscation and disruption; the development and maintenance of socio-political connections in cyberspace that thwart problems of alienation; the production of metadata to serve counterpublics; and various tactics to achieve and preserve privacy such as the use of free and open-source software (F/OSS) to eliminate their role as implicit workers in the digital value chain while embracing communitarian values. Recently, cooperative platforms that function as non-profit marketplaces have emerged in the health sector (e.g. Midata, Savvy.coop) and financial sector (e.g. Datavest) to enable consumers to maintain control of their personal data while connecting with professionals.

Although the range of creative strategies among producer and consumer crowdworkers appears continually expansive, remarkably, the strategies aimed at producer and consumer crowdwork have been mutually exclusive, rendering solidarity among producer and consumer crowdworkers remote. As approaches to resistance continue to unfold, conceivably the apparent consumer/producer binary may dissolve beyond sites of prosumption to articulate a distinct frontier of resistance that draws from common ground.

One impediment to solidarity in the digital era is the unevenness of consumer and producer participation in the digital economy. Producer and consumer crowdworker populations overlap, although at this point in time consumer crowdwork reflects the activity of perhaps billions of people worldwide while producer crowdwork is more in the millions. According to Pew Center surveys in the United States, almost 25 per cent of the adult population sought wages online by November 2016 (http://www.pewinternet. org/2016/11/17/gig-work-online-selling-and-home-sharing/) while about 70 per cent participated in social media by January of 2017 (http://www. pewinternet.org/fact-sheet/social-media/). In the relative infancy of the digital regime of work, it may be a matter of time before crowdworkers recognise and act on the common ground of material and immaterial dispossession wrought of crowdwork, whether implicit or explicit, thereby generating a coalitional movement similar to those that have characterised post-Fordist labour in the global economy. The main goal of a coalition of workers with different sets of concerns is to converge on general principles. (52)

Although producer and consumer crowdwork differ, as do their intentions regarding income generation, and resistance has followed different paths relative to different concerns--to change conditions of work and to eliminate their position in the digital value chain, respectively--general sensibilities among producer and consumer crowdworkers who resist the constraints of the new regime nonetheless share important similarities. For example, despite differences in intention regarding a wage, platform cooperatives developed among producer and consumer crowdworkers bear similar concerns as those among consumer crowdworkers who develop and sustain the free and opensource software movement (F/OSS): autonomy, preservation of privacy, protection from corporate invasiveness, and embrace of democratic and collaborative principles. Such similarities constitute at least an enabling condition for coalitional action across the traditional consumer/producer divide. The emergence in recent years of 'open cooperatism,' which links commons-based peer production (as in Wikipedia) with entrepreneurs aiming to earn a living wage while producing for the public good is hopeful. (53) Further, the context in which we live is changing rapidly. At this juncture in the digital economy, automation in North America and most of Western Europe lags behind South Korea, Singapore, Germany, and Japan while the rate of growth of automation in China appears highest. (54) Although full automation is unlikely in the near future and automation may create new jobs, firms worldwide increasingly will engage automation as a basic competitive strategy, thereby increasing the rate of worker displacement, especially those with low to medium-level skills. (55) As automation and the rate of worker displacement increase across wide-ranging industries, the relative percentage of people seeking wages through digital means likely will increase, along with a critical consciousness of the problems of dispossessed prosumption they confront as both producer and consumer crowdworkers.

Little victories have become visible: Uber drivers in California have pressured legislators to change gig-economy contracts to include worker rights regularly associated with 'employment', (56) Amazon increased wages in response to criticism from Bernie Sanders, (57) and critical consumers have prompted a national-scale debate in the United States regarding intrusions of new media into privacy. (58) These welcome developments are, however, works-in-progress and ultimately may fall short of long-term goals as gains are unsystematic across crowdsourcing firms and commonly are accompanied by losses and/or persistent problems. For example, increases in wages among Amazon workers occurred along with elimination of bonuses and stock grants, and many Amazon workers considered themselves to be worse off following the wage increase. (59) Similarly, as Uber placed a cap on the number of hours Uber drivers work to assuage concerns about overtired, overworked drivers, algorithmic management has remained intact to ensure continued overtime work. (60) Resistance that crystallises in new policies nonetheless represents milestones that could be enhanced substantially, and crucially, sustained, with coalitional support.

Although the value of coalitions among various segments of the marginalised has long been recognised, old conceptual frames that presume a division between consumption and production require revision if digital subjects are to harness the kinship of their consumer and producer crowdwork in an emergent digital regime of work, and accordingly, begin to organise with an understanding of prosumer realities across a dated divide. At this early stage in the new regime of work, possible futures require critical engagement with the spectrum of changes, including fundamental conceptions of labour. Already developments in the digital economy, such as producer crowdwork, have prompted a revision of the concept of employment because working can result neither in a wage nor employment status with associated rights; similarly, digital consumers have become wageless workers without rights, even if some consumers are unaware of their input to corporate profits and others find satisfaction in online self-curation, self-branding, and crucially, connecting with others. An expansive view of crowdsourcing recognises dispossessed prosumption as the basis of the digital regime of work across production and consumption while differentiating context-specific processes to open analysis to critical comparison among workers regarding exploitation, alienation, dispossession, as well as resistance strategies. Beyond contextual factors, subjectivities among consumer as well as producer crowdworkers also are germane because tech firms study and manipulate them to capitalise on them, a crucial element that anchors digital value chains. An expansive framework of the digital regime of work also is suggestive of a potential coalition between digital consumers and producers that might harness the talents and passions among all crowdworkers towards constructing a better future.

urn:contentItem:5X1W-MSM1-F03R-N47Y-00000-00Disrupting Democracy: When Big Tech Takes Over a City2019-09-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:40:23ZLexisNexisDisrupting Democracy: When Big Tech Takes Over a CitySam Ross-Brown

Sep 13, 2019( The American Prospect Blogs: http://prospect.org/blogs Delivered by Newstex) Rob Gillies/AP Photo Jesse Shapins, director of public realm with Google affiliate Sidewalk Labs, speaks at a public forum about a proposed development on Toronto's waterfront, December 7, 2018. Google's smart city of the future is in trouble. For the past two years, Sidewalk Labs, Google's sister company under Alphabet, has been in talks with local officials in Toronto to redevelop 12 acres of neglected land along Lake Ontario into what it calls a data-driven 'disruption' of urban life. But as details of the project—dubbed Quayside—have begun to emerge, residents and local officials have expressed alarm about what it might mean for their city and their democracy. The final straw came on June 17 with the surprise release of the Quayside master plan: Amid glossy illustrations of a techie utopia, the stubbornly coy document described a project that had mysteriously grown from the originally agreed-upon 12 acres to a mammoth 800 acres, in which public spaces could be shaped and controlled by a private company, and where data privacy protections for residents would be shaky at best.

In the plan, Sidewalk Labs also assigned itself the role of lead developer—though it is not a development company—and called upon the city to invest $1.2 billion in public funds to expand its light-rail system to the new development. On August 2, Waterfront Toronto, the public authority that currently owns the Quayside area and had enthusiastically invited Sidewalk Labs in, threatened to pull the plug if these issues remain unresolved by the end of October. But even if Toronto rejects Sidewalk Labs' proposal, the company's plan points to a privately controlled digital future for cities in need of dollars that Big Tech can provide. FOR ALL ITS UTOPIAN BLUSTER, Quayside is only the latest foray Big Tech has made into the world of urban planning in recent years. In 2016, startup accelerator Y Combinator announced it would begin researching how to create 'the best possible city' with so-called smart technology at its center. Among the questions it planned to ask were 'Can we figure out better zoning laws?' and 'Can we fit all rules for the city in 100 pages of text?' Two years after that, Blockchains, LLC—a company run by cryptocurrency millionaire Jeffrey Berns—bought some 67,000 acres of land in western Nevada to build a futuristic new city with an economy based on—you guessed it—Bitcoin. And in places like Seattle, San Francisco, and very soon, Nashville and Northern Virginia, the tech industry's outsized influence on everything from housing markets to municipal tax codes to transit policy has been undeniable. In 2018, Amazon's HQ2 gambit threw local governments' desperation to attract tech giants into stark relief—giving dramatic new meaning to John Dewey's warning that government may merely be the shadow cast over society by big business. What makes Quayside different is the sheer scope of its plans—and the contempt Sidewalk Labs seems to have for local public institutions. Conceived as a city 'from the internet up,' Sidewalk says Quayside will feature heated bike lanes, underground package delivery, and 'adaptive' traffic lights that prioritize pedestrians. Taking the increasingly ubiquitous[1] 'five-over-one' mid-rise design several steps further, the plan calls for building wooden multistoried buildings zoned for commercial and residential use. At the ground level, adaptable walkways would shift between civic and commercial uses depending on real-time changes in market demands—metrics determined through systemic collection of residents' personal data. To do all this, Sidewalk promises to pump CA$1.3 billion, or $980 million, into the project—big money for any city. The need to expand and enhance public space appears frequently in the master plan, from new parks and plaza designs to those 'adaptable' walkways it touts. But a closer read suggests Sidewalk's definition of 'public' is nothing if not opaque. Instead of being under government control, these spaces would fall under the jurisdiction of something Sidewalk calls the Open Space Alliance (OSA), a public-private partnership that would include government officials, residents, landlords, and tenants. The plan does not specify the scope of the OSA's authority, how it would make decisions, or whether one or another group would hold more sway. It does, however, describe in detail how the OSA's operating budget would be structured, suggesting Sidewalk could enjoy a significant degree of control over the organization. 'The sci-fi isn't just in the gadgets—it's in these fictional authorities they want to create,' says Mariana Valverde, a professor of socio-legal studies at the University of Toronto and member of the Toronto Open Smart Cities Forum, a local watchdog. 'This would only work if it was like a gated community, but they don't want to say that's what they're creating.' It's also unclear what political rights residents may have in those supposedly public spaces. The Canadian constitution guarantees rights of free expression and assembly in public spaces. But spaces that are privately owned come with few, and often no, such guarantees. If, say, workers in a Quayside restaurant go on strike (nearly a third of Canadian workers are unionized), will they have a right to picket on the adaptable walkway? What happens if their demonstration interferes with the OSA's real-time, market-driven plans to convert that walkway into a pop-up farmers market? Who gets final say? Indeed, for all its ambitious language about remaking the modern city, what Sidewalk's master plan reveals most vividly is a serious misunderstanding of how urban planning actually works. 'It's not a plan—it hasn't gone to the city planning department. It's nothing. It's just their ideas and fantasies,' says Valverde. 'Development plans are usually much more specific. It's clear who's doing what. There's no way the City Council would approve this.' MORE THAN ANYTHING ELSE, data collection lies at the heart of Sidewalk's plans for Quayside. Nearly all of the 'smart' technologies touted in the company's master plan depend on an Orwellian collection of personal data of all kinds—in both public and private spaces. Through what it calls 'ubiquitous sensing,' Sidewalk aims to make a vast array of public services responsive to residents' needs in real time: traffic lights that analyze traffic patterns; homes that track residents' behavior to reduce heating costs and lower carbon emissions. Sidewalk even envisions a centralized 'identity management system,' which would apparently function much like a government ID, enabling residents to access public goods like transit and health care. Just how much personal data will be open to collection by Sidewalk is hard to say. In its master plan, the company claims that it will harvest only what it calls 'urban data,' a doggedly vague term which the company defines as 'information gathered in the city's physical environment, including the public realm, publicly accessible spaces, and even some private buildings.' Yet elsewhere in the plan, Sidewalk expands this definition to include data collected in private residences, such as 'tenant or building noise, air quality, and energy use.' To allay privacy concerns, Sidewalk insists it would not monetize data and that all collected data would reside in an Urban Data Trust, an independent body composed of Sidewalk, local companies, municipal officials, and Waterfront Toronto. The trust would then set rules for outside companies—like say, Google—attempting to access and monetize the data. Sidewalk says that all such access requests would be made public. Data trusts themselves are nothing new. In Barcelona, the city government has taken a leading role in regulating the collection and use of data through a public trust. Such data are publicly owned, and their use by private companies is tightly controlled. Citizens can even opt themselves out of certain kinds of data collection and control how their data will be shared. But while Sidewalk points to Barcelona as inspiration for its trust, its plans are very different. Barcelona's trust empowers citizens to take control of their data, share them on their terms, and establishes digital sovereignty as a fundamental right. Sidewalk's plan, by contrast, empowers a private company to collect unclear amounts of data with few, if any, concrete checks on its authority. And even if Sidewalk itself does not monetize the data, there's nothing stopping other companies—say, Google—from doing so. As with the Open Space Alliance, it's very difficult to say how the trust will make decisions or whether one group could hold more sway over the others. Sidewalk's original proposal called for a 'civic data trust,' which might have implied some leadership role for the government. But in its current proposal, 'civic data' has been supplanted by 'urban data,' a term with no legal meaning. Whether this shift signaled some change in how the trust would function is anyone's guess. 'The boundaries are not at all clear,' says Andrew Clement, a professor emeritus of public information policy at the University of Toronto and member of the Waterfront Toronto Digital Strategy Advisory Panel. 'Urban data is a problematic mix of private and public information that's being smooshed together in ways that are really murky.' Because of the lack of legal protections for personal data, in Canada as in most other countries, the potential for abuse is high. According to a 2018 report[2] by Ontario's auditor general, Waterfront Toronto failed to consult with any other levels of government before awarding the project to Sidewalk. Ontario lacks the robust policy framework necessary to regulate a project like this, the report warned, and Waterfront made no attempt to address that. In 2018, Ontario's auditor general recommended that the province pass legislation that more adequately protects residents' personal data and privacy before the Waterfront project moves forward. WATERFRONT TORONTO WAS CREATED with a specific purpose in mind—and it wasn't to build a smart city with Google's sister company. The organization had its origins in Toronto's failed 2008 Olympic bid, with the ultimate goal of revitalizing the city's waterfront in time for the games. The Olympics never made it to Toronto, but the legacy of that bid remains in Waterfront Toronto's bizarre governance structure. Officially a tri-government agency, all of Waterfront's decisions must go through three different levels of government—federal, provincial, and municipal. And unlike other, similar public authorities, Waterfront Toronto is specifically barred from creating subsidiaries, changing local zoning, or borrowing money on its own credit. It even has an expiration date: By law, Waterfront Toronto has a 25-year lifespan, which ends in 2025. Contrast all that with, say, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, an agency with independent funding and a wide scope of authority over the parks and transportation infrastructure in the New York metro area—and of course, no expiration date. It was the finite budget in particular that fueled a kind of existential fear within Waterfront in recent years. Having exhausted its CA$1.5 million in seed money, unable to borrow money on its own to revitalize the area, and with the clock ticking on its very existence, the agency began thinking creatively about how to achieve its goals. In March 2017, Waterfront put out a request for proposals[3] (RFP) for an 'innovation and funding partner' to redevelop Quayside. Going well beyond the scope of a typical RFP, Waterfront said its new funding partner would work with the agency to 'create the required governance constructs to stimulate the growth of an urban innovation cluster, including legal frameworks.' Sidewalk Labs, an 'urban innovation organization' founded less than two years prior, jumped at the chance. That October, Waterfront announced Sidewalk had won. The choice of Sidewalk was unusual for a few reasons. For one thing, Sidewalk was a technology company, not a developer, and had no prior experience designing urban spaces. But from the very beginning, Waterfront made it clear that it was looking beyond more traditional funding partners like private developers, and toward technology companies and nonprofits. 'What we are looking for is a partner who for themselves may have done something like this, a demonstration project,' said Waterfront CEO Will Fleissig in April 2017. 'Or may have some technologies they may want to try out, and put their seed capital into it.' Once it found out that Sidewalk was interested, Waterfront went out of its way to give the company a competitive edge. According to a 2018 report[4] by the Ontario auditor general, Waterfront shared information with Sidewalk about the project even before issuing the RFP. This helped Sidewalk develop what was reportedly the most comprehensive bid. Other bidders were not quite so lucky. Waterfront Toronto did not release any of the other bids when Sidewalk was chosen—or even the identities of the other bidders. Typically, Toronto public agencies release details of a bid's three finalists before choosing a winner. Waterfront also kept its preliminary agreement with Sidewalk secret for more than seven months, fueling speculation among city officials and residents. 'Even city councilors couldn't see it. And they're used to seeing everything, especially when it comes to development proposals,' says Valverde. 'That's when I got interested.' WHILE IT'S TEMPTING TO SEE the Quayside project as a corporate takeover of public space and functions, Waterfront's role, particularly in the scope of its RFP, cannot be diminished. Faced with a shrinking budget and a rapidly approaching deadline, the agency did everything it could to attract a corporate partner willing to invest big money. Waterfront 'basically asked a corporation to act as a government,' says Bianca Wylie, co-founder of Tech Reset Canada, a digital watchdog. Yet as Sidewalk has endeavored to become that investor qua government, its honeymoon with actual local governments has rapidly come to an end. Last year, several high-profile officials announced their resignation from Waterfront's board, citing concerns over privatization, data collection, and Waterfront's inept leadership. 'I imagined us creating a Smart City of Privacy, as opposed to a Smart City of Surveillance,' privacy consultant Ann Cavoukian wrote in her letter of resignation in October. Following the release of Sidewalk's master plan this past June, Cavoukian told[5] Canadian tech outlet BetaKit that little had changed. In August 2018, Waterfront CEO Fleissig himself resigned. That December, Fleissig's successor Michael Nobrega defended[6] Sidewalk's proposed data collection practices and committed to holding the company to high privacy standards. Nobrega also shrugged off allegations of bias in its selection process: 'We want to be crystal clear—our RFP processes are competitive, fair, and follow best practices.' That sympathetic attitude evaporated quickly, however, when Sidewalk released its master plan in June, designating itself the lead developer, expanding the area it is developing to 800 acres, and demanding $1.2 billion of public funds for transit expansion. On June 24, Waterfront Toronto responded by sending Sidewalk Labs an open letter[7] outlining its concerns. Taking care to emphasize that Waterfront had had no part in creating the master plan, the agency reminded Sidewalk that, for any of this to move forward, it would need the approval of both Waterfront and the Toronto City Council. In sharp contrast to the agency's erstwhile boosterism, the letter ended on a decidedly noncommittal note: 'Whether the Quayside project proceeds or not, the conversation we are having is important for all of Toronto.' On August 2, the agency announced[8] it would extend its initial agreement with Sidewalk through March 2020 in order to work through unresolved issues and give the public more time to sift through the master plan. But that extension came with a big caveat: If these issues remain unresolved by the end of October, the project would be dead. In announcing the deadline, Waterfront officials seemed to have no problem imagining a future without Sidewalk. 'If for whatever reason [the project] was not to go ahead,' spokesperson Andrew Tumilty told[9] the Toronto Star, 'we're still committed to exploring how we can solve some of these great urban challenges that Toronto and cities around the world face.' For Valverde, the question is less what happens in Toronto and more what Quayside might mean for the future of urban governance. 'This plan is not necessarily for Toronto. There's so little in it that's actually specific to the city,' she says, adding that Toronto may have been a kind of test run. 'It's possible that the real customer is the rest of the world and other cities more desperate for investment.' Indeed, even with the Toronto plan still on the table, Sidewalk seems to be moving in that direction. On September 3, the company announced[10] a partnership with the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan to form something called Sidewalk Infrastructure Partners. Apparently inspired by Sidewalk's work in Toronto, the spin-off company will help cities 'enable sustainable, distributed and intelligent urban infrastructure, creating jobs, improving mobility, and providing more environmentally friendly infrastructure solutions,' in the words of Sidewalk's CEO Dan Doctoroff. Whether such plans move forward in Toronto or anywhere else, what is clear is that the public sector is wholly unprepared for the kinds of disruptions Big Tech is preparing to unleash on urban life. Waterfront Toronto may have been uniquely vulnerable, but any public authority would be, at best, befuddled in the face of one of the largest companies on the planet, bent on reshaping how it functions. From protecting personal data to defending the democratic process, governments at all levels have struggled to respond to a sector with a habit of moving far faster than regulators. And while Big Tech firms like Google are eager to fill that vacuum of power, they seem uninterested in the types of accountability, responsiveness, and transparency that are central to democratic decision-making. If governments in Canada and the United States are unable to get out in front of the changes that Big Tech is proposing, the future of cities may begin to resemble Sidewalk's master plan: stylish, 'smart,' and with little room for the public.
